options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: None
Virtual seminar only
We did a number of research assignments and group assignments outside of class
seminar

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This is a great introductory English course both in the exploration of poetry but also in how to properly write a college-level analytical paper.
You'll learn the basics of (close) reading, interpreting, and writing about poetry, both 18th/19th-century and some contemporary.

Entering this course, I was definitely wary of tackling older poetry, but I feel I left ENGL 126 with the capabilities necessary to approach a number of poetic styles, forms, and voices spanning centuriesas well as the ability to discuss them meaningfully with others.
A broad reading of modern English language poetry
Literary analysis, brief overview of modern poetry from the 1700s to now, writing analytical essays
This course helped me to develop my skills as a reader of poetry, paying particular attention to sound and images.
poetry analysis
My skills writing about poetry definitely improved comparing my first essay to my last in the course.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: In-class discussions are very engaging and Professor Campbell cares so much about her students. She gives extremely detailed and thorough feedback on papers. The range of poetry we read was also pretty diverse.

This course addresses a nice range of authors within the scope of poetry in English from the 18th century to the 21st century. It is only unfortunate that there is not enough time to discuss all of the poems in class, and the three papers only afford so much opportunity to dive into a few of them as well.

Given the unprecedented remote format of this semester, I think ENGL 126 went as smoothly as it couldve. I feel we have all the course material the time and space it warranted, and our discussions were always rich, informed, and multi-faceted.
We did a fair bit of reading but rarely discussed even a small percentage of it.
I found the discussions in this class to be fruitful and thought-provoking. More often than not, my own ideas came after a particularly enlightening comment from a classmate.
I enjoy the happy, friendly atmosphere of the class very much

I felt that our discussions did not often go to very creative or unusual depths, and I often felt that I would have liked to have deeper context or learn more about the works in conversation with other authors at the time. In particular, we read the works of several queer authors and never really discussed any queer theory or how their identities could have impacted the body of their poetry.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This was a very engaging class even in a virtual environment. Professor Campbell really helps bring the class energy up and together.

As noted above, I think that this course went as smoothly as possible given the necessary alterations in light of the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite the virtual format, we managed to have rich and personal conversations each meetingand this was especially amplified by our Rest & Revisit days, which provided us a chance to come together more casually and get to know one another as classmates and peers.
Group assignments outside of class time really aren't best for a virtual environment. Having additional zoom calls was really a drag and the assignments did very little to enrich my learning
The class discussion is very efficient and interactive
I felt that our seminar sessions were very engaging, although I was sometimes unclear about deadlines and Canvas discussion posts (and other students I spoke to felt the same).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Take this class if you are looking to fulfill an introductory requirement for the English major or if you just want to learn more about poetry.

I would recommend this course to anyone who is considering majoring in English, who is interested in reading poetry in English, or who has a general interest in literary analysis at an introductory level.
Yes! Jill Campbell is amazing and so very kind. I'm not sure what the course is like with other professors, but if you have the chance to take it with her, do it!!

Yes! Any student with an interest in poetry should consider taking ENGL 126; the wide range of poetry covered makes it an exciting and engaging course for those interested in a number of poetic styles and periods.
Not really. There are so many better English courses in poetry
Yes, I would recommend this course to any student hoping to better understand English poetry or literary analysis.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student. I found that I am now a better reader, not just of poetry but of literature as a whole.
Yes. The professor is very nice and considerate, and the class is lovely. You'll read beautiful poems, too.
I would recommend this course to a student who is very interested in learning about the canon of English poetry, particularly those of very well known authors.
